item.name: Send Login Endpoint Events
with Random Data (use sparingly)

request.description:
Send a `$login.succeeded` event to Castle's `/authenticate` endpoint. 

[Castle API Documentation](https://docs.castle.io/api_reference)

Send a `$login.failed` event to Castle's `/track` endpoint

[Castle API Documentation](https://docs.castle.io/api_reference)

item.description:
Use newly-generated, randomized data

**NOTE: USE SPARINGLY**
These requests generate a new `user_id`, `User-Agent`, IP address, and even new random request headers

**Under most circumstances, you will want to use this folder to make a single request**

After you have generated new (random) data, the collection variables will persist that data for requests in other folders from this collection.

exec: // TODO: ensure randomized IP is not private
"User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) HeadlessChrome/86.0.4238.0 Safari/537.36"\

item.name: with Persistent Data

request.description:
Send a `$login.succeeded` event to Castle's `/authenticate` endpoint. 

[Castle API Documentation](https://docs.castle.io/api_reference)

Send a `$login.failed` event to Castle's `/track` endpoint

[Castle API Documentation](https://docs.castle.io/api_reference)

item.description:
Use data saved in the collection variables to assign `user_id`, `User-Agent`, and other values.

These requests use data saved in collection variables. Should you desire, you can assign local or environment variables to the same variable names, and your local or environment variables will overwrite the values saved in the collection variables.

After you have generated new (random) data, the collection variables will persist that data for requests in other folders from this collection.

item.description:
Use *mostly* data saved in the collection variables to assign `user_id`, `User-Agent`, and other values. 

**Overwrite specific variables such as `IP`, or `User-Agent`**

These requests use data saved in collection variables. Should you desire, you can assign local or environment variables to the same variable names, and your local or environment variables will overwrite the values saved in the collection variables.

After you have generated new (random) data, the collection variables will persist that data for requests in other folders from this collection.

Send events related to an application login endpoint
- `$login.succeeded`
- `$login.failed`

item.name: User Impersonation (Ignore Events)

exec: // TODO: ensure randomized IP is not private
"User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) HeadlessChrome/86.0.4238.0 Safari/537.36"\

request.description: Start an impersonation session for a random `user_id`, using randomly-generated context data.
Track a `$logout.succeeded` event. As long as the stored `context.client_id` and `user_id` have remained consistent since impersonation began, this event will end the impersonation session.

item.description:
Impersonate a user

Castle's `/v1/impersonate` endpoint can be used for "admin" scenarios when you do not want to track the activity for a given `user_id`. An example would be when a support team member is impersonating one of your users - you wouldn't want to track that support team member's activity on the user account.

The impersonation will act on a randomly-generated `user_id`, which will then be saved in the collection variables for use with subsequent requests. This can be overwritten by a `user_id` defined in local or environment variables.

Castle allows each fingerprint (the `request.body.context.client_id`) to actively impersonate one user at a time. Multiple support team members can impersonate multiple end-users at a time. One support team member can only impersonate one end-user at a time.

request.description: Delete all data about a user
Initiate a request to compile user data. The resulting user data will be emailed to the privacy email address on file (change the privacy email via your Castle Dashboard settings)

variable.value: {"Accept":"text/html","Accept-Encoding":"gzip","Cache-Control":"no-cache","Content-Type":"multipart/form-data","Content-Length":100,"Connection":"close","User-Agent":"Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) HeadlessChrome/86.0.4238.0 Safari/537.36"}
